title-group.article-title: The effect of information on oversight: the European Parliament’s response to increasing information on comitology decision-making

abstract.p: The European Parliament, like any parliament, needs information for scrutinizing executive decision-making. But how does it process this information in practice? This article focuses on the European Parliament’s increasing grip on ‘comitology’ decision-making: committees composed of national civil servants, producing executive measures that are adopted by the European Commission. Two types of changes are addressed: organizational changes and changes in working methods of EP staff. The analysis shows that the European Parliament has effectively built up a system of decentralized police-patrol oversight, but not following more information rights as such but rather as a result of its increasing political powers. The article concludes that information only affects the behaviour of the European Parliament in combination with very specific as opposed to quite general or diffuse political rights.

sec.title: Points for practitioners
sec.p: This article traces the effects of information on the functioning of the European Parliament as an accountability forum. It concludes that information only makes a difference when coupled with very specific as opposed to very general or diffuse political rights.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The European Parliament, like any other parliament, needs information in order to be able to function. For its legislative function, expert information is vital so that members of parliament are able to make sound decisions with respect to the effectiveness of a particular policy. For its function of overseeing the executive and holding it to account, members of parliament need information that makes them aware of the wheelings and dealings of the executive. Although generally information on executive decision-making is of paramount importance for parliaments, the relevance of different types of information depends on the type of control that is exercised. From a checks and balances perspective, for instance, information is required that reveals whether or not the executive has exceeded its discretionary powers that are specified in legislation. A popular control perspective, by contrast, would point to information on the input and output of executive decision-making processes, in order for the legislator to be able to judge what particular preferences have in fact been translated into policies and how, and what have not been. Finally, a learning perspective would mainly require evaluative information in order for the legislator to learn from past events (Bovens et al., 2008).

In much of the literature on government transparency and accountability in general, an ‘automatic link’ is assumed from transparency, or rather, the availability of information, to accountability (Naurin, 2007). It is assumed that the mere fact that a principal is informed of the behaviour of an agent makes the agent act more in line with the preferences of the principal – whether because the agent anticipates the response of the principal or because the principal in fact responds to the information he receives (e.g. Huber, 2000; Lane, 2005; Lupia, 2006; Strøm, 2000). Information, thus, seems something of which a parliament cannot have enough. Even though the availability of more information does not necessarily make government more accountable in itself, information does contain the cues to which parliaments respond. Thus, processing information is an important precondition for evaluating the performance of government, and setting the wheels of accountability in motion (Bovens, 2007; Naurin, 2007).

But in this respect only little is known about how the European Parliament processes information. Previous work mainly addresses this issue both in abstract terms as part of a broader concept of oversight, as well as with a focus on West-European and American national parliaments (e.g. McCubbins and Schwartz, 1984; Saalfeld, 2000). This is surprising given that accountability is an issue of major concern with respect to European Union policy-making (e.g. Bovens et al., 2010; Gustavsson et al., 2009; Papadopoulos, 2010). Over recent years the repertoire of instruments available to the European Parliament in order to hold the Commission accountable has increased (Bovens et al., 2010). Nevertheless such instruments can only work to their full potential when sufficient information comes in and when this information is actually processed.

In this regard it must also be remembered that the European Parliament cannot easily be compared to national parliaments in Europe. All Western democratic parliamentary systems have well-established systems of interacting with the executive that are mediated by political parties (Saalfeld, 2000), making control of the executive to a great degree a party political matter (Peters, 2009). But the European Union works differently from the standard model. Although the legislative powers of the European Union are shared between the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers, only the European Parliament has scrutiny powers. Also, it consists of parties and transnational party groups that do not support the Commission by means of a permanent coalition of parties. This means that majorities need to be built for accepting amendments to proposed legislation, but also for budget approval or for opposing executive measures adopted by the Commission.

This contribution focuses on the processing of information by the European Parliament. More specifically it homes in on information on comitology: an executive decision-making mode acting under the auspices of the Commission that deals with about 60 percent of all European executive measures, and for which the European Parliament has fought a long institutional battle in order to get information and control rights (Brandsma, 2010). This means that comitology is not ‘just’ another mode of governance, but actually the main decision-making process when it comes to adopting executive measures. How does the European Parliament process information on comitology in the context of holding the Commission to account? This is the question that is central to this contribution.

The analysis is split into two parts. After a brief introduction on comitology and the EP’s stance towards it, the first part of the analysis presents how the parliament’s scrutiny powers and its information rights regarding comitology have developed. The second part analyses on the basis of interviews with EP staff – to whom the task of processing information is delegated – how the EP internally manages the flow of information on comitology decision-making. The article concludes that, even though in the past the EP has strongly bargained for more information so as to facilitate it in taking political action, information hardly seems to have made a difference in practice.

sec.title: Comitology and the European Parliament
sec.p: The EP has shown itself to be very interested in controlling the executive measures that are adopted by the Commission. Obviously, executive acts are less far-reaching than legislation, but executive acts contain all the specific provisions that will effectively be applied and have an impact on the lives of citizens and the prospects of businesses throughout the community.

Since the 1990s, several efforts have been made to increase the transparency of the Commission towards the general public (Brandsma et al., 2008; Hix, 1998; Lodge, 1994; Peterson, 1995). Simultaneously, the EP has fought a long battle regarding access to Commission documents and scrutiny powers of its executive activities as well. This battle was fought out especially visibly in the realm of comitology (Bradley, 2008; Türk, 2003). Comitology refers to a set of about 250 committees that are chaired by the Commission and staffed by member state civil servants, who discuss and vote on executive measures. About half of all executive Decisions, Directives and Regulations are adopted via comitology, and in addition it also deals with many executive measures that take a different form, such as annual working programmes. In total, comitology produces between 2000 and 2500 executive measures per year (Brandsma, 2010). This makes comitology the main executive governance tool within the European Union.

The practice of establishing comitology committees has existed ever since the first years of European integration because the member states feared they would lose control over policy implementation when delegating this to the Commission. Given the fact that only member state civil servants are represented in the committees, the power of the EP has long been a contested issue. Throughout its history, the EP has consistently objected to comitology, mainly for two reasons. The first is that the Parliament wishes to be on equal footing with the Council (Bergström, 2005; Bradley, 2008; Neuhold, 2008). The Council and the EP are co-legislators, but participation in comitology committees is kept exclusive to member state representatives only. This structure made the EP fear that the Commission and the member states were able to strike politically significant deals in implementation measures instead of in normal legislation, thereby bypassing the EP (Bergström, 2005).

The second reason is that, according to the EP, comitology undermines its prerogative of executive scrutiny. As any parliament, the EP has been endowed with the task of scrutinizing the executive. However, its formal ties to the executive are mainly with the Commission as an institution. The Parliament holds the view that it should be able to control the executive in full, including comitology (Neuhold, 2008). The Commission, however, has long held the view that comitology decision-making should not be subject to parliamentary control because the committees consist of member state representatives and are only chaired by the Commission. Until the Court of Justice ruled otherwise in 1997, the Commission used this as an argument for not making committee proceedings available to the public and to the EP (Brandsma et al., 2008).

These two reasons lie at the heart of over 40 years of inter-institutional quarrelling over the Parliament’s status vis-à-vis comitology. By means of strategically blocking the legislative process, limiting the validity of certain legislation – and hence also curtailing the possibility of implementing measures via comitology – to a fixed number of years (the so-called ‘sunset clauses’) and at times even freezing parts of the Commission’s budget, it managed to secure an increasing number of scrutiny powers and information rights over comitology (Bradley, 2008). This shows that the EP has very strong feelings about this, and one may therefore expect that the strengthening of the Parliament’s information rights and scrutiny powers has brought about changes in its organization. But before going into this in more detail, it is important to underline first which specific rights the Parliament actually has, and which it gained in recent years.

sec.title: The European Parliament’s powers of scrutiny
sec.p: If the EP wants to take action against a comitology issue, it can choose between several options. Two of these are special rights that the EP enjoys for comitology only, and two more are generic rights that have always been in the EP’s repertoire.

sec.title: The ‘droit de regard’ or right of scrutiny (RoS)
sec.p: This right was introduced in the 1999 Decision on the functioning of the comitology system, allowing the Parliament to oppose a draft measure when the proposed measure exceeds the implementing powers provided for in the basic instrument. The ‘droit de regard’ only applies when the draft measure is based on a co-decision act. The Parliament can express its opposition within one month of receiving the draft measure and does so by means of a non-binding resolution. Apart from very exceptional circumstances, such a resolution first has to be voted upon by the relevant parliamentary committee, and then in plenary by means of an absolute majority.1

Conditions for using this right are thus very restrictive. The ‘droit de regard’ includes only one possible reason for objection that is extremely restrictive; and because majorities in both the EP committee and in plenary are required, whereas the EP only has plenary meetings once a month.

sec.title: The regulatory procedure with scrutiny (RPS) and opposition to delegated acts
sec.p: The regulatory procedure with scrutiny was agreed upon in 2006, although it builds upon a special privilege that the EP has enjoyed since 2003 in the field of financial services. As with the ‘droit de regard’, the regulatory procedure with scrutiny allows the EP to oppose a draft measure. However, such opposition does have binding effects and it may be based on reasons other than power abuse. The Parliament may also object because a draft measure is not compatible with the aim or content of the original co-decision act, or because it does not respect the principles of subsidiarity or proportionality. As a result of the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, this procedure will gradually be replaced by the delegated act procedure provided for in the Treaty itself, which equips the EP with unlimited grounds for objections and also the possibility of revoking the delegation of powers to the Commission. Another change is that the comitology committees involved are turned into expert groups of national administrators, which means that they lose their voting power (Brandsma and Blom-Hansen, 2011).

A resolution for objection has to follow the same route: first it has to be accepted by the relevant parliamentary committee before it can be voted upon in plenary. Under the RPS regime, the Parliament has three months to express its objection in plenary, as opposed to only one month under the ‘droit de regard’. Again, this right only applies when the draft measure is based on a co-decision act that specifies that the Parliament can make use of such powers.2 Under the newly established delegated acts procedure, time limits have changed to two months, extended by another two months if the Parliament has in the meantime announced that it considers adopting a resolution (Brandsma and Blom-Hansen, 2011).

As a general rule, the RPS procedure applies when the resulting implementing acts can modify or add to so-called ‘non-essential elements’ of the original co-decision acts (i.e. annexes). Since the Lisbon Treaty changes the legal basis of Commission executive decision-making, it is not yet fully clear to which additional cases the new delegated act scheme will apply.

The above two rights cannot be used in a generic sense. Which of the two special rights applies is a matter that has to be negotiated when the original legislative act is decided upon between the Council and the Parliament. But besides the ‘droit de regard’ and RPS, the EP can also resort to two further courses of action that it can always use at its own discretion, either separately from or in addition to the two courses of action already mentioned.

sec.title: The right to make statements
sec.p: The EP can always adopt resolutions in order to make political statements. These have to follow the procedure as the above-mentioned resolutions, from individual MEPs, via a committee, to plenary.3,4 The other institutions are not bound to such resolutions in any way, but nevertheless resolutions bear a strong political message that may still have an impact.

A telling example is the Commission decision to put body scanners on the list of allowed security measures at airports. The Transport committee of the EP decided not to formally object to the measure, but the Civil Liberties committee drafted a statement against the use of body scanners which was accepted as a resolution in plenary. The Commission took account of this message and decided to withdraw body scanners from the list (Hardacre and Damen, 2009).

sec.title: Bargaining
sec.p: Given that parliamentary committees (primarily) deal with legislative proposals, they can express their discontent in legislative negotiations with the other institutions on related issues. Because many pieces of legislation have to be revised after a number of years, the other institutions can expect stronger future demands from the EP if it feels unhappy about the adopted implementing measures. Similarly, parliamentary committees can also threaten to draft a resolution and rally support under the RPS scheme unless certain other commitments are made by the Commission on related files.

All of these options have in common that control is effectively exercised at the level of the parliamentary committees. Although resolutions have to be routed via plenary, the actual initiative to take such measures normally follows from the committees, which as the following section will show in more detail are also the key actors in the parliament’s information regime on comitology.

sec.title: The European Parliament’s information rights
sec.p: The Parliament’s successes in obtaining more scrutiny rights from 1999 onwards also necessitated the conclusion of working agreements between the Parliament and the Commission on document forwarding. The 1999 Comitology Decision already pointed out which documents the EP was entitled to receive in order to enable it to perform its right of scrutiny, but it did not further specify the conditions and procedures under which those documents were to be forwarded.

For that reason, the Parliament and the Commission concluded a bilateral agreement in October 20005 – well over a year after the entry into force of the 1999 Comitology Decision. It repeats the 1999 Decision in mentioning that the Parliament is to receive draft agendas for meetings, the results of voting, a list of authorities to which the member state representatives belong, summary records of the committees’ discussions and draft implementing measures that were submitted to the committees, the latter only when these are based on a co-decision act. According to the bilateral agreement, the Parliament was to receive those documents at the same time and on the same conditions as the committee members. The elaborate versions of the committees’ minutes, however, were not to be forwarded to the EP. However, pursuant to a Court ruling a few years earlier, the Parliament may request access to those minutes as well as to draft implementing measures that are not based upon a co-decision act.6 Since the EP has no scrutiny rights in those fields concerned, such documents could only be requested for information only. The Commission also committed itself to forward such documents electronically once the technical arrangements for that had been made.

For measures that relate to the financial services sector, extra information arrangements were made between the EP and the Commission between the years 2001 and 2004 which also relate to the EP’s special scrutiny powers in that field (see above). By means of a letter from Commissioner Bolkestein, the Commission and the Parliament agreed to set up regular meetings between the two institutions: monthly meetings between the secretariat of the EP’s committee on Economic Affairs and the Commission services in DG Internal Market, and regular meetings between the Commissioner and the coordinators and rapporteurs within the Economic Affairs committee (European Commission, 2001). Also, it was agreed that Commission officials would inform the EP of the discussions in comitology committees and that they would be obliged to answer any questions from the EP on such discussions, either orally or in writing.

In 2008, a new bilateral agreement between the EP and the Commission was concluded.7 It includes the same provisions as the 2000 agreement and reiterates the extra agreements that were made for the financial services sector. The only difference from the previous arrangements is that minutes are now explicitly classified as confidential documents, so that penalties can be applied if such documents are leaked. On top of the pre-existing arrangements, the new agreement also mentions the establishment of a new document register, maintained by the Commission and to which the EP has direct access, which contains all documents forwarded from the Commission to the EP including the stage of the procedure of decision-making and timetable information. The agreement also states that the EP will continue to receive documents on an individual basis by e-mail.

So far, we have seen that the European Parliament has generic as well as specific scrutiny powers over comitology decision-making at its disposal, and also that it has acquired information rights over the past decade. The sheer number of comitology meetings per year (about 1000), the number of measures discussed in them (about 2000 to 2500) and the short time the EP usually has to adopt resolutions when it is able to do so (one to three months) already are indicative of the time pressure under which the Parliament has to operate. It must also be pointed out here that the EP was not ‘drowned’ by the Commission sending it all sorts of information on comitology at its own discretion, but that the EP has in fact been very persistent in requesting to be sent all these specific documents for many years (Bergström, 2005; Bradley, 2008). Given the many positive effects that the literature attributes to the availability of information, such as government effectiveness (Drew and Nyerges, 2004), actual pursuit of the legislator’s preferences (e.g. Strøm, 2000) and popular control (Bovens, 2007), and further given the very strong interest that the EP has traditionally had in gaining information rights for comitology, one would at the very least expect to see its organization adapt to the changing circumstances. Before the EP’s system of processing all this information is elaborated, the next section first explains the research design of the empirical part of this study.

sec.title: Data and methods
sec.p: The empirical part of this study ‘follows’ the trail of documents sent by the Commission, and closes in on two distinct types of changes in the EP’s administration. The first are structural changes: were responsibilities re-allocated, and to whom? How was the organizational structure adapted to the new situation? The second type are changing working methods of EP support staff who work with comitology documents on a day-to-day basis. How do they handle the vast amount of comitology documents? And how do they make MEPs aware of comitology issues?

Data have been collected by means of interviews. Since the task of processing information on comitology has been delegated to the EP’s administrators (Kaeding and Hardacre, 2010), eight staff members were interviewed. Six support parliamentary committees and are in charge of informing MEPs directly on comitology affairs. Two further staff members working on comitology coordination or providing practical support on comitology horizontally in Parliament have also been interviewed. All respondents were promised anonymity. The low number of interviewees is due to the fact that, as subsequent paragraphs will show, only a few of the EP’s 18 committees deal with comitology files on a regular basis.

sec.title: The Parliament’s response to increasing amounts of information
sec.p: Previous research into the processing of information by parliaments has shown that they have different ways of dealing with information. The famous study by McCubbins and Schwartz (1984), for instance, distinguishes between police-patrol and fire-alarm type regimes, in which the former refers to a system in which parliaments place governments under active information requirements, whereas the latter refers to a system in which parliaments rely on third parties to monitor governments, implicitly or explicitly on their behalf, who only alert parliaments in cases where they feel parliamentary attention is necessary.

For comitology, the EP organized a police-patrol form of oversight for itself, but in a decentralized form (cf. McCubbins and Schwartz, 1984; Ogul and Rockman, 1990). Figure 1 shows a diagram of this procedure and shows that information on comitology committee proceedings follows a lengthy route from the Commission DGs that manage the comitology committees, via several Commission and Parliamentary services, to the responsible parliamentary committees. Between the Commission and the members of the parliamentary committees, two possible levels of change can be identified: changes in the attribution of responsibilities and changes in the working methods of EP administrators, who in turn inform members of parliament. These will now be addressed in turn.

sec.title: Organizational changes
sec.p: The increasing flow of information and powers of the EP vis-à-vis comitology decision-making have brought about two changes in the EP’s organization. They concern the secretariats of the parliamentary committees as well as the Parliament’s Receptions and Referrals Office. The Receptions and Referrals Office is the place where all documents sent to Parliament, whether by mail or electronically, are received and forwarded to the relevant people in the EP. With respect to comitology documents, this means that all incoming documents are forwarded to the secretariats of the parliamentary committees that were involved in drafting the original co-decision act upon which the Commission’s implementing measures are based.

The first change is that the system of how to forward the vast number of comitology documents gradually changed. Initially, the Commission did not put in the subject line what the topic of the message was, and the Receptions and Referrals office just forwarded all the incoming documents without systematically organizing them (Respondent 2). But especially from 2006, when the Parliament received more scrutiny rights under the aforementioned RPS, the need for a more systematic document handling system arose (Respondent 5). In May 2009, the Receptions and Referrals Office started using a new database system called ‘EPGreffe’ in which the Commission’s secretariat-general uploads small packs of documents. The Receptions and Referrals Office then selects to whom these documents are to be forwarded, and also checks if, where necessary, all language versions are actually included in the document packages (Respondent 8). The appropriate parliamentary committee secretariat then receives the documents in an e-mail attachment (Respondents 1, 2, 4 through 8).

Additionally, the Commission has committed itself to making comitology information available in a more structured and user-friendly format, both in terms of information sent to the EP as well as information released to the general public (European Parliament and European Commission, 2008). Besides sending information to the EP via the Receptions and Referrals Office, the Commission also installed its own comitology register to which EP committee staff have access. This includes the same information, but it makes it easier to find related or additional documents in the same dossiers. In practice, most EP administrators use the information that they receive via the Receptions and Referrals Office and only use the Commission’s database – if at all – when they need additional information (Respondents 1, 2, 5, 6, 7). Only one respondent primarily makes use of the Commission’s register (Respondent 4), and some also mention receiving information directly from Commission staff (Respondents 1, 5).

The second change, which also took place in the EP’s committee secretariats, is that dedicated staff members were recruited as from 2006. Within the Receptions and Referrals Office, one person was made responsible for handling comitology information, and within all Parliamentary committee secretariats a comitology contact person was appointed (Respondents 1 through 8). Some committees that deal with a relatively large number or heavy comitology issues (Economic Affairs, Environment and Transport) were able to hire an extra secretary because of this (Respondents 3, 5, 7).

Although these changes took place in the aftermath of new information agreements between the Parliament and the Commission with respect to comitology, ‘more information’ has not been their unique driving force. With respect to the first change, it does seem plausible that the new document handling system – including the allocation of a dedicated member of staff to the Receptions and Referrals Office – does indeed follow from a practical need to handle a vast amount of documents in an efficient way. But also, this need only became pressing after 2006 when the EP received more scrutiny rights (Respondent 5). There seems no relation with the number of documents that the EP receives on a regular basis, since it has been receiving large volumes of comitology documents ever since the year 2000. The number of committee meetings, for instance, and therefore also the number of agendas and meeting summaries, has been around the 1000 mark over recent years (European Commission, 2006, 2009). The same can be said with respect to the second change. The parliamentary committees that have the highest comitology workload indeed were able to recruit extra staff members, but only after the 2006 Comitology Decision gave the EP an extra right of scrutiny. This too does not follow logically from the information rights that were installed in the year 2000.

The above shows that more information alone did not bring about organizational changes in the EP. The most significant rise in the amount of information sent to the EP, as Table 1 shows, was in the year 2000, whereas the organizational changes happened from the year in which the EP gained an extra political right: from 2006. This suggests that the need to organize information flows in an accessible manner only arises when it is instrumental to a specific parliamentary right (in this case: the right to overturn committee opinions) as opposed to an addition to existing general rights such as controlling the executive by means of asking questions.

sec.title: Working methods of EP staff
sec.p: Students of parliamentary oversight have occasionally addressed the role that parliamentary support staff play in stimulating members of parliament to act upon their inputs, thereby strengthening their own positions within the system (Aberbach, 1990; Ogul and Rockman, 1990). Dedicated staff for comitology affairs have been absent from the EP’s committees for a long time. Only since 2006 have a small number of dedicated administrators been appointed in the parliamentary committee secretariats that are explicitly responsible for comitology matters. As a result of this, it is not possible to detect changes in their working styles as a result of more EP information rights that were put in place before their appointment.

What can be observed as a result of the 2006 changes and the appointment of dedicated staff members, however, is that an informal coordinating network (the ‘comitology network’) was set up by the Codecision and Conciliations Unit, a unit of the EP that on a horizontal level deals with inter-institutional decision-making. The comitology network meets several times a year and brings together the comitology contact persons of the parliamentary committee secretariats, as well as staff members of the political groups. The aim of the network is to share practical problems and find common solutions or best practices, both when it comes to drafting new legislation and when keeping track of implementing measures. With respect to the latter issue, topics that are discussed frequently are, for example, the changes introduced by the Lisbon Treaty, dealing with deadlines and, interestingly, how to make MEPs aware of the importance of comitology (Respondents 1, 3, 5, 6; see further below).

There are significant differences between parliamentary committees with respect to the workload that comitology brings within their policy domains. There are four committees that receive more dossiers than others under the right of scrutiny and the regulatory procedure with scrutiny: Transport, Development, Agriculture, and, especially, Environment (Respondents 3, 8). Those committees, thus, have more information to process than the other committees. Do their administrative staff, who deal with information processing, have working methods that are different from those of the staff who have to process much less information on comitology affairs?

Within the ‘lead group’ of four committees, three comitology administrators were interviewed. Upon receipt of information from the Reception and Referrals Office, one respondent forwards each and every package of information directly to all MEPs in the committee, including an abstract of the files attached and an internal deadline before which MEPs are to let the secretariat know they would like to discuss an objection within the committee (Respondent 2). In the Environment and Transport committees, which out of these four committees also work on the bulk of the RPS files, the packages of information are collected and forwarded together with a newsletter that includes a brief summary of the attached files (Respondents 5, 7, 8). In one committee, further background to the issues is also provided by means of the newsletter (Respondent 5). The newsletters are produced between twice a week and every fortnight. This does mean that some time is eaten up by this procedure from the one to three months that the EP has to adopt a resolution in the committee and in plenary, but this way it is easier for MEPs to digest the information. In one committee, some MEPs prefer not to receive all the e-mails, but the secretariat feels it is a political responsibility to select important files, not an administrative one, and therefore still forwards all individual measures (Respondent 7).

In the remainder of the committees, practices are varied as well. This partly has to do with the working culture within the committees. In one committee, all files are forwarded to all members of the committee (Respondent 4), whereas in another committee these are only forwarded to the coordinators of the political groups within the committee, together with a short background note (Respondent 6). In one exceptional case, the secretariat filters out important RPS measures and forwards these to the chairman of the committee and the rapporteur of the co-decision act upon which the comitology measure is based, together with an assessment of what course of action would be most appropriate (Respondent 1). In none of those committees, however, are newsletters produced.

Again, it appears that a higher information load in itself does not have an impact on how EP staff members handle the incoming information, as one of the committees that are responsible for handling relatively more comitology issues applies the same working methods as those who manage relatively few issues. The distribution of newsletters is limited to the two committees that both have a high information load and work on RPS measures relatively often, being the committees of Transport and Environment. This shows again that a higher level of information in itself does not affect work practices within a parliament, but that it only has an impact in combination with more extensive and specific parliamentary powers.

sec.title: Political implications
sec.p: How, then, do these changes in the Parliament’s information system and its handling of the information therein relate to the activities of MEPs? After all, this is what the Parliament’s information system is meant to support. As mentioned before, the EP has four instruments at its disposal: a right of scrutiny resolution on the legality of a certain measure; more extended veto rights under the regulatory procedure with scrutiny; the ability to make political statements through other resolutions; and the ability to threaten with all of the above in the course of a bargaining process with other institutions.

Measured by the frequency by which the EP deploys any of these instruments, it does not seem likely that the changing information regime has greatly affected parliamentary behaviour simply because it only rarely takes action in the first place. Between the introduction of the ‘droit de regard’ in 1999, and 2010, the EP adopted only nine resolutions on the grounds of power abuse. This low number may not be surprising given the fact that the Parliament only has one month to adopt such resolutions in plenary, and that these resolutions are not binding. In fact, they only oblige the Commission to ‘reconsider’ its measures which in a political sense means giving further explanation on the contested measure (Lintner and Vaccari, 2009). The final decision thus lies with the Commission, which adopted the acts in the first place and generally does not give way to parliamentary concerns about their legality (Neuhold, 2008).

But the other rights are also hardly used in practice. Until the summer of 2010, the regulatory procedure with scrutiny, which was introduced in 2006, had resulted in just three parliamentary vetoes (Kaeding and Hardacre, 2010). Five further veto attempts failed in committee, and one final veto attempt was voted down in plenary by a very narrow margin (Kaeding and Hardacre, 2010). Those numbers in relative terms are substantially higher than with the ordinary right of scrutiny, but remain quite low in absolute terms. Even lower figures can be seen for other courses of action, such as making political statements through resolutions. Besides Parliament’s success with respect to body scanners, mentioned earlier (see Hardacre and Damen, 2009), only two further resolutions of this type were adopted between 1999 and 2005 (Lintner and Vaccari, 2009). Only once has a veto threat alone made the Commission withdraw its measure, and twice was a veto threat used as a bargaining chip for future legislative processes (Kaeding and Hardacre, 2010).

Thus, all in all the harvest of ten years of parliamentary scrutiny rights is rather meagre when compared to the vast number of measures on which the EP receives information. Obviously failure to put forward objections, in whatever form, may be indicative of consent to the adopted measure, but it is observationally equivalent to parliamentary working structures hindering scrutiny or to a lack of awareness more generally. At the very least, one might have expected to see comitology affairs discussed more often during committee meetings. It has recently been put forward that the lack thereof may have to do with lack of political interest in technical matters for which tight deadlines apply (Kaeding and Hardacre, 2010), and this also corresponds to the reading of insiders. There are very few reactions to comitology documents, so that comitology issues are only rarely placed on the parliamentary committee’s agenda (Respondent 2). According to an experienced official who works on horizontal comitology issues, before 2007 neither MEPs nor EP officials cared about comitology at all (Respondent 3). But gradually, interest rose as a result of the new possibilities that the regulatory procedure with scrutiny brought to the EP, and because the aforementioned ‘comitology network’ helped the committee administrators in raising awareness.

This also brings us, again, to procedural incentives as an alternative but stronger explanation. The introduction of the regulatory procedure with scrutiny in 2006 led to changes in the EP’s document handling system, and EP committee support staff also disseminate information in a more accessible format when a committee handles a relatively large number of RPS measures. Despite its tight deadlines, the relative strength of the RPS procedure also stimulates interest in controlling decision-making because resolutions adopted pursuant to the weaker ‘right of scrutiny’ do not have binding effects (Respondents 1 through 5). The implication of this is that the EP’s information regime is partly disjointed from the control that it exercises in practice. Overall, selection is based on procedural incentives as opposed to content.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In many policy documents as well as in many studies of governance, transparency is hailed as the panacea for confronting almost all the EU’s alleged legitimacy problems, from increasing its legitimacy in a more general sense (e.g. Corbett et al., 2000; Eriksen and Fossum, 2002) to, specifically, increasing popular trust (Majone, 2000), government effectiveness (Drew and Nyerges, 2004) and control over the executive (Héritier, 2003). Especially in the latter part of the literature, an ‘automatic link’ is assumed from transparency, or the availability of information, to accountability (Naurin, 2007). It is assumed that the mere fact that principals are informed of the behaviour of an agent make it act more in line with the preferences of the principals (e.g. Huber, 2000; Lane, 2005; Lupia, 2006; Strøm, 2000).

This article has investigated how the EP processes information on comitology decision-making. Although it is not possible to find out empirically what the outputs of comitology decision-making would have been in the absence of parliamentary control, one would expect the EP to use information on comitology to a great degree. It has expressed interest in controlling comitology ever since the early 1960s, and started receiving more information on comitology at the turn of the century. This was expected to have a major impact on the degree to which the Parliament takes action with respect to comitology decision-making.

Even though information is seen as a necessary precondition of accountability (Bovens, 2007), this article has shown that the increase in information on comitology seems to have hardly affected the way in which the EP controls it. Although the Parliament has always had means of controlling comitology at its disposal, it did not enjoy substantial ‘special’ scrutiny rights until 2006. From the interviews it appears as if the Parliament did not respond to increasing amounts of information per se, but rather it has been waiting for extra scrutiny rights before beginning to process incoming information systematically. Only then did changes take place in the EP’s organization and in the working methods of its administrative staff.

New changes in the EP’s scrutiny rights are under way. As was already briefly mentioned before, the Lisbon Treaty has introduced a split in the legal basis of comitology decision-making between ‘delegated acts’ (Article 290) and ‘implementing acts’ (Article 291). The delegated acts regime provides for parliamentary control rights which are slightly broader than the current regulatory procedure with scrutiny, as well as for an informal system of member state expert groups. The implementing acts regime is very closely modelled on the traditional comitology system, excluding the regulatory procedure with scrutiny (Brandsma and Blom-Hansen, 2011). If current practices of information processing continue, it seems likely that the EP will focus on controlling delegated acts since this comes with more procedural incentives, while leaving implementing measures barely attended.

As the above exploration shows, overseeing comitology measures on a day-to-day basis is a daunting task, and for many committees too much for MEPs to handle all on a structural basis. On this note, it seems plausible that MEPs in practice rely on fire alarms which by definition are of a more accidental nature (Türk, 2003). But as previous research has shown, probably only true insiders can trigger fire alarms in a useful way. For that, the information on comitology that is publicly available on the internet reflects too little of the discussions in the comitology committees, both in terms of quantity and of quality (Brandsma et al. 2008).

The assumed link from information to parliamentary behaviour, thus, is far from automatic. Transparency itself is not the magic cure that improves or even strengthens government accountability all by itself. But the case of comitology and the European Parliament does show that it is a necessary component together with other conditions in order to be able to make full use of the available repertoire of control instruments. Two lessons can be drawn in this respect. The first is that the volume and quality of information that recipients receive is not sufficient for producing effects. Rather, what it takes is the processing of the information (Brandsma, 2010; Naurin, 2007). The crucial question for the exercise of control by parliaments, thus, seems not to be how much information it receives, but rather how the interest of members of parliament is distributed between issues and to what degree they actually make use of the available information. The second lesson is that procedural incentives seem to make actors in parliaments engage with the information provided. Information provided to a parliament only becomes relevant when members of parliament can see the link between the information they receive and specific as opposed to more diffuse political rights.
